patterns.content: HIGHT (High Security and Light Weight) is a 64-bit lightweight block cipher developed by KISA in 2006 for resource-constrained environments. Block size: 64 bits. Key size: 128 bits. Rounds: 32. Structure: Generalized Feistel Network. Designed for RFID, USN, IoT devices. Quantum vulnerability: 64-bit block size is weak, 128-bit key becomes 64-bit effective against quantum.
patterns.quantum_resistance: Weak - 64-bit block cipher vulnerable to birthday attacks, 128-bit key â†’ 64-bit quantum security

patterns.content: HIGHT implementation patterns: import hight, from hight import HIGHT, HIGHT_encrypt(), HIGHT_decrypt(), hight_key_schedule(). Lightweight crypto libraries for embedded systems.
HIGHT in IoT/embedded configurations: cipher: HIGHT-128, lightweight_cipher: HIGHT, block_algorithm: HIGHT-64. Common in Korean IoT devices, smart cards, RFID tags.
patterns.note: 64-bit block size is vulnerable to Sweet32 attack

patterns.content: HIGHT binary signatures: HIGHT_Encrypt, HIGHT_Decrypt, HIGHT_KeySchedule, HIGHT_F0, HIGHT_F1 functions. Characteristic constants: delta array for round key generation. 32 rounds with simple operations (XOR, rotation, addition).

HIGHT security concerns: 64-bit block size vulnerable to birthday attacks after 2^32 blocks (~32GB with same key). Quantum: Grover reduces 128-bit key to 64-bit security. Sweet32 attack possible with long sessions. Recommend migration to 128-bit block ciphers.
patterns.recommendation: Replace with AES-128 or LEA-128 for IoT, ASCON for ultra-lightweight

patterns.content: HIGHT standards: Korean standard TTAS.KO-12.0040 (2006), ISO/IEC 18033-3:2010 Amendment 1 (2021), Lightweight cryptography for IoT/RFID, Evaluated by CRYPTREC.
HIGHT usage: RFID/NFC tags, smart cards, wireless sensor networks (WSN), IoT devices (esp. Korean market), embedded systems with limited resources. Hardware-efficient design but security limitations.

HIGHT detection priorities: CRITICAL - Long-running sessions (>2^32 blocks), HIGH - Production IoT devices, MEDIUM - Test/development environments. Check for block counter limits and key rotation policies.
patterns.note: 64-bit block ciphers should not encrypt more than 32GB with same key
